column3: The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.

column2: adjective: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach
column3: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.

column2: verb: to make nervous or upset
column3: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly “Magoosh-ing”, and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.

column2: adjective: having never been done or known before; novel
column3: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.

column2: adjective: creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression
column3: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.

column2: adjective: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success
column3: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.

column2: adjective: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to authority
column3: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene—unless it's nap time.

column2: adjective: without scruples or principles
column3: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

column2: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
column3: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.

column2: adjective: very generous
column3: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

column2: adjective: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified
column3: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.

column2: adjective: unfavorable; inconvenient
column3: Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.

column2: adjective: not confined or limited
column3: untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

column2: adjective: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).
column3: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.

column2: verb: to reproach; to scold
column3: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"—in the end he had to upbraidthe apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

column2: adjective: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social experience
column3: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophistcate spy James Bond.

column2: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
column3: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

column2: adjective: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance
column3: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.

column2: verb: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict
column3: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.

column2: noun: the quality of being different
column3: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to lie”.

column2: adjective: highly or widely praised or boasted about
column3: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.

column2: adjective: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
column3: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

column2: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
column3: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

column2: noun: covering consisting of a thin superficial layer that hides the underlying substance
column3: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.

column2: verb: to respect deeply
column3: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was veneratedamongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

column2: adjective: easily excused or forgiven; pardonable
column3: His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious—on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.

column2: adjective: truthful
column3: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

column2: noun: the appearance of truth
column3: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

column2: adjective: truthfully, without a doubt
column3: Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

column2: adjective: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of another
column3: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can—through hundreds of intimate "tweets"—vicariously live the life of a famous person.

column2: noun: change in one’s circumstances, usually for the worse
column3: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes—massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.

column2: verb: compete for something
column3: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.

column2: verb: spread negative information about
column3: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

column2: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
column3: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

column2: adjective: to have a very strong desire for revenge
column3: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.

column2: noun: an ill-tempered or violent woman
column3: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago’s invective—she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

column2: noun: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will
column3: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racism that consumed his whole life.

column2: adjective: harsh or corrosive in tone
column3: While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

column2: adjective: to criticize harshly; to berate
column3: Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.

column2: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
column3: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around an look at them angrily.

column2: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
column3: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

column2: adjective: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto
column3: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.

column2: adjective: lacking
column3: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

column2: adjective: without check or limitation; showing no moral restraints to one's anger, desire, or appetites
column3: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.

column2: verb: to gradually increase in size or intensity
column3: Her enthusiasm for the diva’s new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.

column2: adjective: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
column3: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.

column2: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
column3: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

column2: noun: spirit of the times
column3: Each decade has its own zeitgeist—the 1990’s was a prosperous time in which the promise of the American Dream never seemed more palpable.

column2: noun: the highest point; culmination
column3: At the zenith of his artistic career, Elvis was outselling any other artist on the charts.
